Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Situation2: They travel a long distance to participate in an important religious festival, ensuring they fully engage in all rituals and offerings.
Story:
I sat cross-legged on the cool marble floor, the scent of incense curling around me as my relatives bustled about, preparing for the family puja. My mother’s voice echoed in my mind, reminding me how important it was to uphold our family’s traditions. This year, I was expected to lead the ceremony, reciting the prayers and guiding everyone through the rituals, just as my grandfather once did. I felt the weight of their expectations pressing on my shoulders.

But my heart was torn. Just yesterday, I had arrived in this city after a long, exhausting journey, determined to participate in the grand festival at the temple—a festival that only happens once every twelve years. As a Hindu, I knew how important it was to immerse myself in every ritual, every offering, to honor my faith and connect with the divine. Yet, the family ceremony was scheduled at the same time as the main temple procession. I could feel my chest tighten as I imagined disappointing my family or missing the spiritual experience I had traveled so far for. The voices of duty and devotion clashed inside me, and I sat there, paralyzed, unable to choose.
